required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018

clinical_study.brief_title: MAIN STUDY: Low Glycaemic Index (GI) Diet in the Management of GDM SUB-STUDY: The Breast Milk Sub-Study
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of a Low GI Diet on Maternal and Neonatal Markers of Glycaemic Control and Postpartum Diabetes Risk SUBSTUDY The Effect of a Low GI Diet on Postpartum Markers of Oxidation in Breast Milk of Women With Gestational Hyperglycaemia

brief_summary.textblock:
MAIN STUDY: Low glycaemic index (GI) diets are recommended by the Canadian Diabetes Association for treating type 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus (DM), but the role of GI in the management of gestational diabetes(GDM)is not yet clear. The main purpose of this study is to determine the effect of a low GI diet on blood sugar control in women with GDM. The effect of a low GI diet on maternal oxidative stress, pregnancy and delivery outcomes and markers of risk for diabetes after birth in both the mother and baby will also be assessed. SUB-STUDY: The main purpose of the sub-study is to determine if the breast milk (BM) of women with GDM consuming a low GI diet will have a higher antioxidant capacity than the BM of women receiving a medium-high GI diet (control/standard care). The effect of a low glycaemic index diet on maternal dietary intake of specific nutrient-antioxidants (i.e. vitamin C, E, and beta-carotene) (prenatal and postpartum) and concentration of vitamin C, E, and beta-carotene in participants' transitional and mature BM will also be assessed. The ORAC (Oxygen radical absorbance capacity) assay will be used to assess overall antioxidant capacity. The antioxidant capacity of BM in women with GDM will also be compared with that of women without GDM.
Hypotheses:
MAIN: The use of low-GI foods in the management of GDM reduces postprandial BG and oxidative stress; thereby reducing maternal and infant perinatal complications.
SUB-STUDY: Breast milk (BM) of women with GDM consuming a low GI diet will have higher BM antioxidant than women receiving the medium to high GI diet. BM of women with GDM will have lower antioxidant capacity than that of women without GDM.

detailed_description.textblock:
MAIN STUDY: Use of low GI education is currently accepted by the Canadian Diabetes Association in treatment of type 1 and 2 DM, but is not included in the clinical practice guidelines(CPG) for management of GDM. Data collected to date support use of low GI in treatment of GDM, but more data are needed to influence CPG. In this study the effect of a low GI diet on maternal and neonatal markers of glycaemic control and postpartum diabetes risk in mother and baby will be determined. This study will also assess the role that maternal oxidative stress may play in this relationship.
Hypothesis: The use of low-GI foods in the management of GDM reduces postprandial BG and oxidative stress; thereby reducing maternal and infant perinatal complications.
SUB-STUDY: Breast milk (BM) is accepted as the optimal source of nutrition for infants. A wealth of literature on BM composition exists. This work includes measurement of antioxidants in BM. Women diagnosed with gestational hyperglycaemia have decreased antioxidant capacity in comparison to normoglycaemic pregnant women. A direct relationship exists between postprandial glycaemic response and oxidative stress. Low GI carbohydrate is converted to blood glucose (BG) more slowly than medium to high GI carbohydrate
Hypotheses: Breast milk (BM) of women with GDM consuming a low GI diet will have higher BM antioxidant than women receiving the medium to high GI diet. BM of women with GDM will have lower anti-oxidant capacity than that of women without GDM.

primary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Percentage of postprandial self monitored blood glucose (SMBG) values within the target range
primary_outcome.description: SMBG values are obtained 4 times daily (1 fasting and 3 postprandial) throughout the study from the randomization to delivery. The endpoint is a single value for each participant - namely the percentage of all the postprandial SMBG values within the target range recommended by the Canadian Diabetes Association (5.0 to 6.6 mmol/L)

primary_outcome.measure: SUB-STUDY (n=75): Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC) (Antioxidant Capacity) of transitional and mature breast milk.
primary_outcome.description: Breast milk samples (25 mL) will be collected 1 week and 8 weeks after birth from a complete breast milk collection. Measures will be compared between and within groups.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Infant birth weight
secondary_outcome.description: Weight of the baby at delivery in grams.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Percentage of self-monitored fasting glucose values within the target range
secondary_outcome.description: SMBG values are obtained 4 times daily (1 fasting and 3 postprandial) throughout the study from the start of the intervention to delivery. The endpoint is a single value for each participant - namely the percentage of all the fasting SMBG values within the target range recommended by the Canadian Diabetes Association (3.8 to 5.2 mmol/L)

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Glucose variability
secondary_outcome.description: SMBG values are obtained 4 times daily (1 fasting and 3 postprandial) throughout the study from the randomization to delivery. This endpoint is the coefficient of variation of all the SMBG values obtained (CV = 100*SD/mean), where SD is standard deviation; a single value for each participant.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Insulin prescription incidence
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of women prescribed insulin during the intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Mean fasting glucose
secondary_outcome.description: SMBG values are obtained 4 times daily (1 fasting and 3 postprandial) throughout the study from the randomization to delivery. The endpoint is the mean of all fasting SMBG values obtained - a single value for each participant.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Mean postprandial glucose
secondary_outcome.description: SMBG values are obtained 4 times daily (1 fasting and 3 postprandial) throughout the study from the randomization to delivery. This endpoint is the mean of all postprandial SMBG values obtained; a single value for each participant.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Mean post-breakfast glucose
secondary_outcome.description: SMBG values are obtained 4 times daily (1 fasting and 3 postprandial) throughout the study from the randomization to delivery. This endpoint is the mean of all SMBG values 2 hours after breakfast; a single value in each participant.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Mean post-lunch blood glucose
secondary_outcome.description: SMBG values are obtained 4 times daily (1 fasting and 3 postprandial) throughout the study from the randomization to delivery. This endpoint is the mean of all SMBG values 2 hours after lunch; a single value in each participant.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Mean post-dinner blood glucose
secondary_outcome.description: SMBG values are obtained 4 times daily (1 fasting and 3 postprandial) throughout the study from the randomization to delivery. This endpoint is the mean of all SMBG values 2 hours after dinner; a single value in each participant.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in LDL oxidation at 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from randomization in LDL oxidation at 4 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: Difference between LDL oxidation measured in fasting venous blood at randomization and 4 weeks.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: LDL oxidation 6-8 weeks after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: LDL oxidation measured in fasting venous blood 6-8 weeks after delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC) of plasma at 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC) of plasma measured in venous serum at randomization and 4 weeks.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in c-reactive protein (CRP) at 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in CRP from randomization at 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in c-reactive protein concentration in venous serum from baseline at 4 weeks.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Post-partum CRP
secondary_outcome.description: Concentration of venous serum c-reactive protein 6-8 weeks after delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Post-partum fasting serum glucose
secondary_outcome.description: Venous fasting serum glucose 6-8 weeks after delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Post-partum serum glucose concentration 2 hours after consumption of 75g oral glucose (2hrPC serum glucose).
secondary_outcome.description: Venous serum glucose concentration 2 hours after consumption of 75g oral glucose (oral glucose tolerance test).

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Incidence of post-partum impaired glucose tolerance
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of women with venous serum glucose concentration 2 hours after a 75g oral glucose tolerance test between 7.8 and 11.0 mmol/L, inclusive.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Incidence of post-partum diabetes mellitus
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of women with diabetes 6-8 weeks after delivery. Diabetes is defined as fasting serum glucose greater than or equal to 7.0 mmol/L and/or serum glucose 2 hours after 75g oral glucose tolerance test greater than or equal to 11.1mmol/L.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Maternal weight gain
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-pregnancy to delivery: up to 9 months
secondary_outcome.description: Difference between reported pre-pregnancy body weight and last body weight measured before delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Rate of maternal weight gain
secondary_outcome.description: Difference between maternal body weight at randomization and last body weight measured before delivery divided by the number of weeks between the measurements.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in infant weight
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in infant body weight from birth to 6- 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Difference between infant birthweight and weight 6-8 weeks after delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY & SUB-STUDY (n=75): Maternal dietary intake
secondary_outcome.description: Dietary analysis will be conducted using software containing the Canadian Nutrient File, supplemented with data that used standardized GI testing methodology. Comparison will be made between and within groups.

secondary_outcome.measure: SUB-STUDY (n=75): Concentration of vitamin C, E, and Beta-carotene in transitional breast milk
secondary_outcome.description: Concentration of vitamin C, vitamin E and beta-carotene in breast milk collected 1 week after delivery. Comparison will be made between and within study groups.

secondary_outcome.measure: SUB-STUDY (n=75): Concentration of vitamin C, E, and Beta-carotene in mature breast milk
secondary_outcome.description: Concentration of vitamin C, vitamin E and beta-carotene in breast milk collected 6-8 weeks after delivery. Comparison will be made between and within study groups.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Infant demographics
secondary_outcome.description: Collection of infant demographics, such as gestational age at birth, sex, incidence and type of complications as noted in maternal or infant chart, mode of delivery, length of stay in hospital

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in infant body measurements from birth to 6-8 weeks post-partum
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in infant body measurements from delivery to 6-8 weeks post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Weight, head circumference, and height/length

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Infant APGAR score at delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Infant APGAR score at delivery as recorded in maternal medical chart.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in maternal blood pressure and resting pulse from randomization to 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Difference between maternal blood pressure and resting pulse from randomization at4 weeks.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Maternal blood pressure and resting pulse at 6-8 weeks post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Maternal blood pressure and resting pulse at 6-8 weeks post-partum.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Infant waist circumference at 6-8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Infant waist circumference at 6-8 weeks.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in ultrasound measurements from randomization to delivery.
secondary_outcome.description: Difference between infant ultrasound measurements (Bi-parietal diameter, head circumference, abdominal circumference, and femur length) from baseline to delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Maternal height at baseline
secondary_outcome.description: Maternal height at baseline

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Maternal medical history
secondary_outcome.description: Maternal medical history

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Maternal medical complications from baseline to 6-8 weeks post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Incidence and type of maternal medical complications from baseline to 6-8 weeks post-partum

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in maternal weight from delivery at 6-8 weeks post-partum
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Difference between delivery and 6-8 weeks post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in maternal weight from delivery at 6-8 weeks postpartum.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Maternal pre-natal demographic information
secondary_outcome.description: Maternal pre-natal demographic information (e.g. ethnicity, language used at home, household food preparation and purchasing, education obtained, employment status, treatment of diabetes, prior exposure to a registered dietitian, cigarette, recreational drug, and alcohol use before and during pregnancy, and physical activity) using a pre-tested, face-validated questionnaire.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Maternal post-partum socio-demographic data related to infant feeding practices
secondary_outcome.description: Socio-demographic factors previously identified in the literature as affecting infant feeding practices; including access to breastfeeding education while in hospital.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Length of time between delivery and maternal breast fullness
secondary_outcome.description: Length of time between delivery and maternal breast fullness.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in conjugated dienes at 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Difference between conjugated dienes of plasma measured in venous serum at baseline and 4 weeks.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Conjugated dienes post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Conjugated dienes in fasting venous blood 6-8 weeks after delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC) of venous plasma post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: ORAC measured in fasting venous blood 6-8 weeks after delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in full lipid profile at 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in full lipid profile of plasma from baseline at 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in full lipid profile of fasting venous blood at baseline and 4 weeks.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Full lipid profile post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Full lipid profile of fasting venous blood at 6-8 weeks post-partum

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in incidence and severity of symptoms from baseline to 6-8 weeks postpartum
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6-8 weeks postpartum
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in the incidence and severity of maternal symptoms present from baseline to 6-8 weeks postpartum using a standardised questionnaire.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Infant feeding practices
secondary_outcome.description: Maternal infant feeding practices from delivery to 6-8 weeks postpartum

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Participant satisfaction of baseline education class
secondary_outcome.description: Participant reactions and opinions on baseline education class using a face-validated, pre-tested questionnaire.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in participant knowledge of GI from baseline to 6-8 weeks after delivery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in GI knowledge from randomization to 6-8 weeks after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in participant knowledge of GI from randomization pre-education class) to 6-8 weeks after delivery using a face-validated, pre-tested questionnaire.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Participant knowledge of GI at baseline
secondary_outcome.description: Participant knowledge of GI at baseline (pre-education class)using a validated questionnaire.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in participant opinion on availability and acceptability of study diet foods
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in opinion from 2 weeks to 6-8 weeks after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in participant opinion on availability and acceptability of study diet foods from 2 weeks to 6-8 weeks after delivery using a validated questionnaire.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Difference in dietary GI between study groups.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 6-8 weeks after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in dietary GI between study groups from baseline to 6-8 weeks post delivery using a short-form semi-quantitative food frequency questionnaire (FFQ). The FFQ collects dietary intake data on the 3 months preceding administration. The FFQ has been standardised and evaluated for readability by nutrition professionals, clinicians and/or researchers with experience in surveying, and has been face-validated and pre-tested.

secondary_outcome.measure: MAIN STUDY: Change in behaviour from baseline (pre-class) to 6-8 weeks after delivery.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in behaviour from baseline (pre-class) to 6-8 weeks after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in behaviour within and between groups from baseline (pre-class) to 6-8 weeks after delivery using face-validated, pre-tested questionnaires, including a short-form semi-quantitative food frequency questionnaire (FFQ). The FFQ collects dietary intake data on the 3 months preceding administration. The FFQ has been standardised and evaluated for readability by nutrition professionals, clinicians and/or researchers with experience in surveying.

arm_group.description: Standard care dietary advice to emphasize high fiber foods with a moderate to high GI
Low GI dietary advice in addition to standard care

intervention.description: Standard dietary advice for women with GDM with special emphasis on use of high fiber or whole grain carbohydrate foods with a medium to high GI. What's on Your Plate? and 3-dimensional food models will be used to teach servings size and meal planning. This groups will be provided with food substitution lists (key-foods method) composed of medium to high GI foods.

Nutrition education according to standard care similar to the control group with supplementary GI-education. GI-education will be taught using the "Stop-Light-Method". This groups will be provided with food substitution lists (key-foods method) composed of low-GI carbohydrate-containing food. The GI-education tool(s) will build on standard care education where patients are taught which food groups contain carbohydrate.

criteria.textblock:
MAIN STUDY
Inclusion Criteria:
Women:
1. ≥ 18 years of age
2. diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) or impaired glucose tolerance of pregnancy (IGTP) according to Canadian Diabetes Association (CDA) criteria
3. being followed within DIP (one of 4 sites)
4. willing and able to give informed consent
5. willing and able to comply with the study protocol
Exclusion Criteria:
Women:
1. with acute or chronic illness other than GDM or IGTP or use of drug (other than insulin) which may affect carbohydrate metabolism, gastrointestinal function or carbohydrate digestion (i.e. crohn's disease, HIV/AIDS, liver disease, kidney disease etc.).
2. known to have type 1 or type 2 DM prior to pregnancy
3. known multi-fetal pregnancy at enrolment
4. ≥ 33 weeks' gestation
5. prescribed oral anti-hyperglycaemic medication
6. insurmountable language barriers
SUB-STUDY control group (women without GDM) Same as for Main study except absence of GDM

overall_official.affiliation: University of Toronto/ St Michael's Hospital

facility.name: MAIN STUDY ONLY: St Joseph's Heathcare Hamilton, 50 Charlton Avenue East

reference.citation: Ceriello A. Acute hyperglycaemia and oxidative stress generation. Diabet Med. 1997 Aug;14 Suppl 3:S45-9. Review.
Ceriello A. The emerging role of post-prandial hyperglycaemic spikes in the pathogenesis of diabetic complications. Diabet Med. 1998 Mar;15(3):188-93. Review.
Huang D, Ou B, Prior RL. The chemistry behind antioxidant capacity assays. J Agric Food Chem. 2005 Mar 23;53(6):1841-56. Review.
Saenz AT, Elisia I, Innis SM, Friel JK, and Kitts DD. Use of ORAC to assess antioxidant capacity of human milk. Journal of Food Composition and Analysis 22:694-698, 2009

Elisia I, Kitts DD. Quantification of hexanal as an index of lipid oxidation in human milk and association with antioxidant components. J Clin Biochem Nutr. 2011 Nov;49(3):147-52. doi: 10.3164/jcbn.10-142. Epub 2011 Sep 3.
Wolever, TMS. The Glycaemic Index: A Physiological Classification of Dietary Carbohydrate. Ontario, Canada: CABI, 2006.
Grant SM, Wolever TM. Perceived barriers to application of glycaemic index: valid concerns or lost in translation? Nutrients. 2011 Mar;3(3):330-40. doi: 10.3390/nu3030330. Epub 2011 Feb 28. Review.
